name: Rhinoceros Iguana
description: This iguana is named for the three protrusions on the forehead of adult males. Males also differ from females by their larger size, more robust dorsal crest, throat dewlap, and femoral pores that secrete pheromones to attract females.
food_note: Leaves, fruits, and other plant parts
image_alt: Rhinoceros iguana, photo: Tereza Mrhálková, Prague Zoo
proportions: Body length 50–75 cm; tail length 50–75 cm; weight 4.5–10 kg
attractions: Like other terrestrial iguanas, it is herbivorous and a significant seed disperser for certain shrubs and trees. Females bury their eggs in sandy soil, seeking warm spots for their burrows and guarding the area for a few days after laying, after which parental care ends.
projects_note: Listed as a vulnerable species on the IUCN Red List, with some subspecies considered endangered. The primary cause of population decline is habitat destruction due to limestone mining, large-scale burning of scrubland, and pollution, compounded by direct hunting for skin and meat.
breeding: Prague Zoo has kept these iguanas continuously since 1991, when a trio arrived from Frankfurt Zoo. Nearly eighty offspring have hatched to date.
